;南非竞争委员会将调查这家美国制药商 ;强生公司强生;对结核病药物贝达喹啉收取高价，并将其 20 年专利延长至 2027 年，以阻止更便宜的仿制药进入该国。

;

;委员会的调查上周，卫生部门和;健康正义倡议; (HJI) 法律组织在;;无国界医生; (MSF)。该委员会在有合理理由怀疑存在剥削或不道德行为时对此事进行调查。

;

;南非贝达喹啉化合物的专利;7 月到期;，但被延长至 2027 年，导致指责 ;常青化;，即药品制造商对药品或其用途进行微小的改变，以保持其在市场上的垄断地位。

;

; HJI 创始人兼董事法蒂玛·哈桑 (Fatima Hassan) 表示：“竞争委员会认为强生可能违反了;《竞争法》第 8 条;，涉及过度定价和排他性行为，在本例中，指的是常青化做法 [因为它导致排除市场上的其他人]。

;

;“我们相信这是前所未有的。我们不知道竞争委员会对一家常青制药公司进行过其他调查。”

;

;南非有一个 ;世界上结核病发病率最高;，并且 – 尽管;结核病是可以治愈的; – 这是该国的;主要死亡原因;。

;

;贝达奎林与其他药物联合使用，用于;治疗耐多药结核病;，这是一种;标准补救措施不起作用;。该药物被认为是一种游戏规则改变者，因为之前的治疗涉及长达两年的痛苦注射，这不仅会导致听力损失等副作用，而且还会产生副作用。 gov/30001994/">;高死亡率;。

;

;南非卫生部门开始向公共卫生部门所有需要的人提供必须服用六个月的贝达奎林;2018 年;。

;

;目前，卫生部门购买了六台每位患者一个月的疗程费用为 5,400 兰特（232 英镑）。但从 10 月 1 日起，与强生签订新合同后，价格将升至 5,500 兰特（236 英镑），而通过遏制结核病合作伙伴关系采购贝达奎林的国家 ;全球药物基金;将仅;支付同等金额2,446 兰特（105 英镑）;。

;

;全球药物基金使用集中采购来谈判付款，这使得为结核病药物讨价还价成为可能。但南非等;拥有公开招标系统;的国家无法合法购买

;

;“我们很愤怒地看到，在一个耐药结核病负担沉重的国家，强生公司将利润置于最弱势群体的需求之上，”无国界医生。 “我们呼吁强生公司向南非政府提供 2,446 兰特的贝达喹啉价格，就像他们向 ;全球药物融资协议;。”

; ;
;

;
;

;在过去十年中，;健康活动人士一直在倡导;修改立法，以便控制常青树。约翰内斯堡威茨大学;农村健康倡导项目;主任拉塞尔·伦斯堡 (Russell Rensburg) 表示：“我们的立法者需要考虑的是，为什么我们要我们还没有制定我们的[专利]法来确保我们不会遭受此类剥削行为。修正专利法对于解决健康不平等问题至关重要。”

;; ; Fri, 22 Sep 2023 13:52:01 +0800 Global push for clean hydrogen foiled by costs and lack of support, report findshttps://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/sep/22/global-push-for-clean-hydrogen-foiled-by-costs-and-lack-of-support-report-finds
;;2023-09-22T05:00:09Z;
;
;;能源公司 Iberdrola 在西班牙 Puertollano 建造的绿色氢工厂
;

;全球推动清洁能源一份报告发现，氢能的发展受到成本上涨和政府“滞后”政策支持的阻碍。

;

;低排放氢能项目的公告正在迅速扩大，但开发商在投资之前正在等待政府支持据国际能源署（IEA）称。报告发现，通过清洁或污染较少的工艺生产的氢气占天然气总产量和使用量的不到 1%。

;

;IEA 执行董事法提赫·比罗尔 (Fatih Birol) 表示，世界已经看到了“令人难以置信的势头” ”近年来低排放氢项目的背后“但充满挑战的经济环境现在将考验氢开发商和政策制定者落实计划项目的决心”。

;
;

;;相关：< /span>;;氢气真的是一种足够清洁的燃料来应对气候变化吗危机？;

;
;

;氢气是一种清洁燃烧的气体，是降低钢铁厂和化工厂等工业设施对环境影响最有前途的燃料之一。但如今，几乎所有的氢都是由化石燃料制成的，其过程会释放地球加热气体。

;

;自俄罗斯全面启动以来，对清洁工艺的投资受到高能源价格、通货膨胀和供应链中断的威胁。报告发现，虽然到 2022 年全球氢需求量将增至 9500 万吨，但增长发生在传统行业，并且几乎完全通过有增无减的化石燃料来满足。 “氢在新应用中的吸收……这是清洁能源转型的关键，但仍然很少，占全球需求的不到 0.1%。”

;

;通过使用氢分解水分子可以更清洁地生产氢来自风力涡轮机和太阳能电池板等可再生能源的电力，或通过捕获传统化石燃料过程中释放的二氧化碳。

;

;但使用第二种方法的项目捕获的碳太少，泄漏太多甲烷，一种比二氧化碳更有害的地球加热气体。科学家们就氢在净化经济方面的作用展开了激烈的争论。

;
;

;;相关：;;只有真正清洁的氢才能帮助解决气候危机 | Malcolm Turnbull;

;
;

;IEA 报告将这两种方法都视为低排放方法，该报告发现，如果所有宣布的项目都得以实现，到 2030 年年产量可能会达到 3800 万吨，尽管到目前为止，各公司已只有4%的项目做出了最终投资决定。在总潜在产量中，2700万吨基于电解，1000万吨基于碳捕获。

;

;报告发现，各国政府已做出一些努力来增加氢的供应，但在鼓励需求方面进展缓慢。 。报告发现，生产氢气的目标为 3500 万吨，但创造需求的目标仅为 1400 万吨。

;

;A ;去年《自然》杂志的研究发现，氢的短期短缺和氢使用方式的长期不确定性正在“危及”气候目标。研究人员发现，即使通过电解生产氢气的能力增长得像风能和太阳能一样快，到 2030 年，通过电解生产氢气的能力将占全球能源需求的不到 1%。

;

;不过，他们补充说，历史上其他行业的例子表明，技术的发展速度与需要的速度一样快。研究人员列举了美国在二战期间战斗机的生产和中国高铁网络的蓬勃发展作为“紧急部署”的例子。

;

;阿德里安·奥登韦勒 (Adrian Odenweller)波茨坦气候影响研究所和《自然》研究的主要作者表示，国际能源署的报告证实，“项目储备正在稳步增长，但由于成本上升和支持计划实施缓慢而受到阻碍”。

;
; < p>;;相关：;;柴郡村民不会被迫参加氢能试验;

;
;

;对于用电生产的氢气来说，这个问题尤其严重。一年前，IEA 预计 2022 年全球电解槽产能将达到 1.4GW。Odenweller 表示，今年的报告发现，2022 年总装机容量为 0.7GW，仅为这一数字的一半。

;

;“这是不幸的，但也不足为奇，”他说。 “氢市场的增长的特点是同时扩大供应、需求和基础设施的具体挑战。我们的研究表明，这会导致绿色氢的短期稀缺和长期不确定性。”

;

;为了生产足够的清洁氢来满足气候目标，国际能源署呼吁制定更大胆的天然气生产支持计划。采取行动刺激需求，并简化许可和批准新项目的流程。它还呼吁各国政府合作，建立一个具有共同标准和规则的国际氢市场。

;

;“这是降低低排放氢成本的关键十年，” IEA 首席能源技术官。

; Fri, 22 Sep 2023 13:52:01 +0800 Rhino numbers rebound as global figures reveal a win for conservationhttps://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2023/sep/22/rhino-numbers-rebound-as-global-figures-reveal-a-win-for-conservation-aoe

;;南部白犀牛在南非漫游
;

;尽管种群数量减少，但全球犀牛数量已增加至 27,000 头新数据显示，犀牛受到偷猎和栖息地丧失的破坏，一些物种十年来首次出现反弹。

;

;20 世纪，非洲和亚洲的犀牛数量约为 50 万头，但其数量已遭到严重破坏。去年，尽管爪哇犀牛和苏门答腊犀牛这两个物种仍接近消失，但它们在一些地区开始显示出恢复的迹象。

;

;保护机构 IUCN 非洲犀牛专家组发布的数据表明，截至去年底，全球犀牛数量增至约27,000头，其中南方白犀牛数量自2012年以来首次增加，从2021年底的15,942头增至16,803头。 2021 年，世界犀牛数量;估计为26,272 头。

;

;原产于东非和南部非洲的黑犀牛因犀角偷猎而严重减少，但去年增加了近 5%，从 2021 年底的 6,195 头增加到截至 2022 年底，数量为 6,487 头。尽管被偷猎者杀死的黑犀牛数量有所增加，但这一增长还是在 ;环保主义者建立了规模不断扩大的新种群;。

;

;“有了这个好消息，我们可以叹一口气十年来首次得到缓解，”世界自然保护联盟犀牛组织主席迈克尔·奈特博士说。 “必须进一步巩固和发展这一积极的发展，不要放松警惕。”

;

;与此同时，爪哇犀牛和苏门答腊犀牛仍然处于极度濒危状态，数量不断减少，并且似乎有可能灭绝。据官方统计，苏门答腊犀牛尚存约 80 头，但专家认为，数量可能;少至 34 头;，通常在小片森林中，它们几乎不可能找到彼此并繁殖。去年三月，;一只雌性犀牛在几次流产后在印度尼西亚出生。

;

;2022 年，非洲有 551 头犀牛被杀害，高于 2021 年的 501 头和 2020 年的 503 头。虽然这些数字仍然令人担忧，与 2015 年危机高峰期相比，2000 年代初期猎杀数量大幅增加，有 1,349 头非洲犀牛被偷猎，数量明显下降。

;
;

;;相关：;< a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2022/dec/18/return-of-the-northern-white-rhino-back-from-extinction">;犀牛回归：我们可以带上北白犀从灭绝中恢复过来？;

;
;

;“我们放心地看到对合作保护行动的长期投资导致白犀牛、黑犀牛和大独角犀牛的数量增加， “拯救犀牛国际组织首席执行官乔·肖博士说。 “必须加强类似的干预措施，以继续解决爪哇和苏门答腊犀牛面临的严峻形势。我们对所有五种犀牛的未来仍然坚定不移。”

;

;在印度和尼泊尔，较大的独角犀牛数量稳定在 4,000 头左右，但自然资源保护主义者仍然对偷猎和栖息地丧失感到担忧。

;

;;爪哇犀牛数量约为 76 头;，全部被发现在印度尼西亚;乌戎库隆国家公园;，但已经出现了;该地区的非法活动;。

; Fri, 22 Sep 2023 12:52:01 +0800 Thailand to clamp down on cannabis use in major U-turn on drug policyhttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/sep/22/thailand-to-clamp-down-on-cannabis-use-in-major-u-turn-on-drug-policy

;;曼谷的一家大麻店。泰国去年将大麻合法化后，将“整顿”其大麻政策。
;

;泰国新任总理 Srettha Thavisin 表示，他的政府将“整顿”其大麻政策，并将其使用限制在医疗目的六个月内。

;

;泰国成为亚洲第一个将大麻合法化的国家;去年将大麻植物作为麻醉品除名;后，导致曼谷等热门旅游目的地大麻咖啡馆和杂草药房的繁荣、清迈和芭堤雅。

;

;然而，未能通过立法来规范其使用，导致该国出现法律真空。

;
;

;;相关：;;泰国梦大麻合法化后高端大麻旅游业的发展;

;
;

;泰国新领导人;8月上台的房地产大亨;表示，联合政府已就需要修改法律并禁止将其用于娱乐。

;

;Srettha 领导为泰党，该党与其他 10 个政党组成联合政府，并在选举前推行强硬的禁毒运动。

; >;

;“法律需要重写，”斯雷塔在纽约参加联合国大会时接受彭博电视台采访时表示。

;

;“需要纠正。我们可以只对医疗用途进行监管。”

;

;当被问及娱乐用途是否会有所妥协时，Srettha 回答“不会”，并补充说，吸毒引起的问题“最近很普遍”。

;

;一些旅游运营商对限制其使用的举措表示欢迎，理由是宽松的行业监管造成的问题。

;

;芭堤雅阳光酒店及度假村集团执行董事 Thanet Supornsahasrungsi 表示，大多数游客的大麻商店用于娱乐用途，并且有大麻过量的报道。

;

;“如果我们想将其用于医疗目的，执法部门应该更加严格，以确保我们可以向它们提供大麻萨尼特告诉《曼谷邮报》。

;

;目前，;任何 20 岁以上且未怀孕或未哺乳的人都可以在其住所和食物中使用大麻;含有其提取物的大麻可以在有执照的餐馆内消费。

;

;在许多亚洲国家，使用和持有大麻会受到严厉处罚和监禁，新加坡对罪犯判处死刑。

; Fri, 22 Sep 2023 12:52:01 +0800 We can’t alter Brexit deal to appease car industry, says European commissionerhttps://www.theguardian.com/business/2023/sep/22/we-cant-alter-brexit-deal-to-appease-car-industry-says-european-commissioner
;;2023-09-22T04:00:09Z;
;
;;蒂埃里·布雷顿站在四个麦克风前
;

;英国脱欧贸易协议不应该仅仅重新启动颇具影响力的欧盟委员蒂埃里·布雷顿 (Thierry Breton) 表示，为了满足英国和欧盟汽车行业部分部门对电动汽车即将征收关税的需求。

;

;欧盟领导人面临暂停征收 10% 关税的压力。根据英国脱欧条约，电动汽车出口预计将于一月开始。

;

;但负责欧盟内部市场并接受《卫报》独家采访的布雷顿表示，欧盟委员会和欧盟领导人有义务根据竞争法，审视整个汽车“生态系统”，而不是偏袒行业中的一个“类别”。

;

;他认为不应取消贸易协议。

;

; Breton 表示：“如果某些事情已经通过谈判，就不应该改变。”

;

;今年早些时候，沃克斯豪尔 (Vauxhall) 和吉普 (Jeep) 等 14 个品牌的母公司 Stellantis 发出了严厉警告，称它可能不得不如果不暂时取消关税，英国的业务将关闭，数千个工作岗位将流失。

;

;他们的呼吁得到了欧洲汽车制造商协会 (ACEA) 的支持，该协会表示，电动汽车出口到除非;英国脱欧; 贸易协议发生变化。

;

;德国最近的支持引发了人们对委员会做出有利决定的预期。

;

;但布雷顿警告说，汽车行业并非由大品牌组成像宝马、大众或沃克斯豪尔这样的公司，他必须确保所有人都有一个公平的竞争环境。

;

;“请记住，汽车行业不仅由制造商组成，而且还由数十万家提供服务的公司组成。汽车所需的一切，包括电池供应商。

;

;“这是一个全球供应链。我称之为生态系统，作为工业专员，我必须关注整个生态系统，而不是这个生态系统的某一部分，”他说。他补充说，每个部门都必须受到公平对待，因为它们根据竞争法享有相同的权利。

;

;“已经谈判的内容已经谈判完毕，我认为在条约达成后遵守条约非常重要。”很难做到这一点。当我们谈论汽车系统时，我必须照顾这个生态系统中的每个人，而不是单一类别。”

;

; Fri, 22 Sep 2023 12:52:01 +0800 Iranian activists across Europe are targets of threats and harassmenthttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/sep/22/iranian-activists-across-europe-are-targets-of-threats-and-harassment
;;2023-09-22T04:00:08Z;
;
;;Shadi Amin 和 Maryam Banihashemi
;

;伊朗及其特工似乎正在策划一场欧洲范围内的袭击针对抗议现政权的政治活动人士的骚扰、监视、绑架阴谋和死亡威胁。

;

;《卫报》采访了 15 名伊朗活动家，他们在英国、法国各地都曾成为类似镇压行动的目标、德国、西班牙、瑞士和瑞典。

;

;在大多数情况下，西方警方或安全机构都警告活动人士，伊朗是对他们生命构成可信威胁的幕后黑手，以报复他们在欧洲领土上的活动.

;

;这些攻击包括黑客攻击、网络攻击和在线骚扰，其中可能包括一周内发送的数千条死亡威胁以及现实世界的威胁。

;

;不同国家的两名活动人士去年，他们的汽车轮胎被割伤，他们怀疑这是伊朗特工干的。有几份报告称，开会后被可疑男子跟踪回家。

;

;伊朗政府发言人否认了所有不当行为的指控。

;

;马赫萨·阿米尼 (Mahsa Amini) 去年因涉嫌犯罪被捕后在拘留期间死亡。据称违反了强制性头巾法，在伊朗各地引发了史无前例的大规模抗议浪潮，威胁要推翻伊斯兰共和国。

;

;在伊朗国内，对抗议活动的反应是残酷的，有 500 多人被杀。游行期间的街道上有大约 20,000 人被拘留。据报道，已有 100 多名抗议者被判处死刑或被指控犯有死刑，其中有 7 人被处决。

;

;伊朗同时寻求平息远离其国境的异议。

;

;其中包括目标是玛丽亚姆·巴尼哈什米(Maryam Banihashemi)，她是伊朗妇女运动在瑞士的代言人，她自 2016 年以来一直居住在瑞士。在公开呼吁伊朗政权更迭后，她已经习惯了在社交媒体上收到死亡威胁。她认为自己在参加政治活动后被跟踪回家，两次是在苏黎世，另一次是在伯尔尼议会与瑞士议员会面后。

; ;

;今年 6 月，Banihashemi 被告知她的生命可能处于危险之中。这条信息是由她认识的伊朗革命卫队工作人员转达给她的，这条信息令人不寒而栗：“他们打算在那里暗杀你。”

;

;瑞士警方此后建议巴尼哈什米更改姓名和地址，并聘请私人保镖，但她说她负担不起。她说：“当我第一次搬到这里时，我很高兴。在伊朗因担任女性首席执行官而遭受多年压抑后，我终于在瑞士感到自由。今年之后，连欧洲对我来说也不安全了。”

;

;另一位收到死亡威胁的人是住在西班牙的伊朗人 Farzane，她要求不要透露自己的姓氏。今年 2 月，她通过一个声称代表伊朗政权的 Telegram 帐户收到了威胁。

;

;西班牙警方无法识别发件人的身份，发件人写道：“我们将在马德里寻找你，我们要杀了你。就像你的其他朋友在伊朗被捕并被处决一样，你也会受到惩罚。”

;

;法尔赞报告说，天黑后，她在马德里参加政治会议后被一个她认为是伊朗特工的人跟踪回家。西班牙警方检查了她的房子并展开调查，但她说两个月后就关闭了。

;

;她继续组织抗议活动，但生活在持续的焦虑状态中。她说：“我正在向西班牙政府纳税，我希望得到保护。 They know the situation, they don't care.”

;

;Elsewhere, security agencies or police are providing some advice or a measure of protection to those who are being targeted. But doing so involves a significant commitment of resources.

;

;Matt Jukes, the head of counter-terrorism policing at London's Metropolitan police, said earlier this year that the force's workload investigating threats from foreign states, many of them emanating from Iran, had quadrupled over the last two years.

;

;He revealed that the UK had foiled 15 plots by Iran to either kidnap or kill UK-based individuals that Iran regards as enemies of the regime.

;

;Shadi Amin, an Iranian LGBTQ+ activist in Germany, was warned by the security services there that she was under threat from Iranian hackers and agents. The police came to her house to check the locks and bolts on the door, and spent weeks inspecting her digital devices, which she was later advised not to use due to the threat from Iran's hackers.

;

;Last month, Germany's domestic intelligence agency issued a public warning about “concrete spying attempts” by an Iran-linked hacker group, Charming Kitten.

; ;

;Despite efforts to protect her, Amin still feels unsafe. “我不能相信任何人——我的处境与 20 世纪 80 年代的伊朗一样。我不能邀请朋友过来，也不能向任何人提供我的地址。 The German government is not in a position to give us the safety that we expected,” she said.

;

;Another LGBTQ+ activist in Germany, Mina Khani, was provided with bodyguards by the state and warned by the German security services that her personal details were being circulated on Iranian hacker forums.

;

;Suspected Iranian hackers have targeted activists in France with phishing attacks and in the UK with attempts to hijack their Google accounts. One sophisticated phishing campaign, detected by an NGO supporting Iranian activists, Miaan Group, targeted journalists and activists outside Iran who used Gmail, trying to trick them with fake Google Drive links.

;

;'Now I constantly watch my back'

;

;When Alireza Akhondi, a Swedish MP of Iranian descent who has been a vocal critic of the Revolutionary Guards, travelled to Brussels earlier this year, Swedish security services advised him to wear a bulletproof vest. Police issued him with a personal alarm for emergencies.

;

;He said that when he first started receiving death threats over the phone, he did not take them seriously.安全机构的警告改变了他的立场。 “Now I constantly watch my back, I take a different route home every day, I check under my car before getting in. I am constantly on the watch,” Akhondi said.

;

;In France, police have issued travel warnings to women organising protests against Iran's regime, warning there is a risk they could be kidnapped by a country that has a long history of hostage-taking. They were specifically warned not to travel to Turkey or the UAE.

;

;“They explained to me that Iran's target is people having a media impact, especially on public opinion,” said Mona Jaffarian, who has led protests in France.

;

;Where Iran has been unable to silence reformers overseas, the regime has targeted their family members in Iran.

;

;Fariba Borhanzehi, a Baluchi activist living in London, testified against Iran's government in the European parliament in April. Two months later, while attending a women's leadership workshop for Iranian activists in London, she discovered that her son, a British resident, had been arrested on espionage charges while visiting Iran and accused of collaborating with British intelligence.

;

;Her son was released on bail in August but has had his UK residence permit confiscated and cannot travel back to London.

; ;

;“When I heard the news of my son's arrest, I felt like I was dying,” Borhanzehi said. “But I refuse to remain silent while my people's rights are taken by a dictatorial government.”

;

;Mahmoud Maleki, a spokesperson for the Iranian embassy in London, said the accusations were unsubstantiated and lacking in evidence, and questioned the motives of those making them. He added: “We can categorically reject all those claims like harassment, surveillance, kidnap plots and death threats, as well as hacking, cyber-attacks and online harassment.”

; Fri, 22 Sep 2023 12:52:01 +0800 ‘The least we can do is care for their children’: Libyans rally to protect Derna’s orphanshttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/sep/22/orphans-children-derna-libya-floods
;;2023-09-22T04:00:08Z;
;
;;Aid workers care for children affected by the floods in Derna
;

;People in western Libya have rallied round to provide care and breastmilk for young children orphaned by the devastating floods that hit the coastal city of Derna on 10 September.

;

;Hundreds of traumatised babies and young children are thought to have lost their parents in Derna, where ;whole neighbourhoods were wiped out; after two dams broke.

;

;“Infant children do not wish to use artificial feeding bottles, which forced us to search for breastfeeding mothers,” said Mona Alashi, a volunteer.

; ;

;Nawal Alghazal, a 62-year-old resident of Benghazi, has started a campaign to collect breastmilk from women already breastfeeding their own children and distribute it to children whose mothers are dead or missing.

;

;“The least we can do for our country and the people in Derna is to take care of their children,” said Alghazal, who has taken 70 young children into her care since the disaster.

;

;Another woman, Marwa Abdelrazzaq, said she was willing to take in a Derna orphan and promised to provide the same care and attention as she does for her own daughter.

; ;

;According to Unicef, children who lose their parents or are separated from their families are more vulnerable to dangers such as violence and exploitation.

;

;Noura Eljerbi, a Libyan journalist, nevertheless cautioned against rushing to relocate children before the paperwork was completed to classify them as orphans, which would increase the likelihood of them being matched with relatives.

;

;Eljerbi estimated that about 400 children separated from their families in Derna are now living in two schools converted into shelters. Every day, desperate people come by the schools searching for missing relatives.

;

;In theory the ministry of social affairs is responsible for caring for orphaned children in the first instance and arranging their long-term care with foster families, but after years of political fracturing and violence, trust in institutions of the state is low.

; ;

;Abdelnabi Abu Araba, a civil activist, said he had received nearly a thousand offers of foster care through his Facebook page and phone contacts. While praising the empathy of his fellow citizens, he also expressed concern that some would-be fosterers were offering to help on impulse after being moved by the horrific scale of the flooding disaster.

;

;Abu Araba emphasised that the ability to provide financial support was not the sole criterion for becoming a foster carer, and that a person's social situation and behaviour should also be assessed. He noted that the social affairs ministry would normally conduct a wide survey of a prospective fosterer before coming to a decision.

;

;The floods in Derna inundated as much as a quarter of the city, officials have said.据搜索小组称，数千人丧生，其中许多人仍埋在废墟下或海上。 Government officials and aid agencies have given varied death tolls ranging from about 4,000 to more than 11,000.

; ;

;More than 43,000 people have been displaced in the area, including 30,000 in Derna, according to the UN's migration agency. Many people have moved to other cities across Libya, hosted by local communities or sheltered in schools.

;

;Local authorities said they have isolated the worst-damaged part of Derna amid growing concerns about waterborne diseases. Health authorities have launched a vaccination campaign that initially targeted search and rescue teams along with children in Derna and other affected areas.

;

;On Monday hundreds of angry protesters gathered outside the main mosque in Derna, where they castigated the political class that has controlled Libya since the dictator Muammar Gaddafi was ;ousted and killed; in a Nato-supported uprising in 2011.

;

;Bushra Kareem, a 37-year-old volunteer, is working to identify children who have made it out of Derna with and without their families and provide psychological support to help them integrate into schools before the academic year starts.

;

;Kareem said that even if children managed to make sense of what has happened to them, reality could become blurred with their imagination, making them susceptible to “severe disturbances” involving fear, anxiety, and other psychological symptoms.

;

;Several social media pages have shared heartbreaking accounts by children recounting the moment when they were swept away by the flood waters.

;

;Kareem said she was encouraging parents to seek the assistance of volunteer psychological support professionals for children and ensure that these children receive psychological support, either individually or in group sessions with other children.

; Fri, 22 Sep 2023 12:52:01 +0800 ‘Swiftposium’: Australia to host academic conference on Taylor Swifthttps://www.theguardian.com/music/2023/sep/22/taylor-swift-swiftposium-academic-conference-australia-university-of-melbourne

;;Taylor Swift performs during her Eras tour in Inglewood, California last month
;

;Australia is set to fulfil student Swifties' wildest dreams when it hosts an international academic symposium in 2024 devoted to the global cultural and economic impact of ;Taylor Swift;.

;

;The three-day “Swiftposium”,; ;hosted by the University of Melbourne from 11 to 13 February 2024, coincides with the singer's Eras tour, which kicks off in Australia at the Melbourne Cricket Ground on 16 February.

;

;Organised by scholars from seven Australian and New Zealand universities, Swiftposium is billed as an “academic conference for scholars to engage in critical dialogue about Swift's popularity and its profound implications for a range of issues including gender, fandom, popular culture, literature, the economy, the music industry, and more”.

;
;

;;Related: ;;How much is Taylor Swift making from the Australian concerts of her Eras tour?;

;
;

;The interdisciplinary conference will be held both online and in-person, including a public event in Melbourne's Federation Square.

;

;On Thursday organisers ;issued a call for academic papers;, with suggested topics such as: “'When my depression works the graveyard shift': Mental health discourse and Taylor Swift”, 'If I was a man, then I'd be The Man': Taylor Swift, and gender and sexuality”, and “'This city screams your name': The impacts of international touring and large events, particularly Taylor Swift, on urban landscapes and the cultural identity of cities.”

;

;Organisers will invite the singer to make a virtual appearance.

;
    ;
  • ;

    ;;;Sign up for the fun stuff with our rundown of must-reads, pop culture and tips for the weekend, every Saturday morning;;

    ;
    • ;
;

;The conference's co-organiser Dr Jennifer Beckett, a senior lecture in media and communications at the University of Melbourne, said academics from a range of disciplines from the ;Asia Pacific; region were invited to submit papers – from urban planning to law to health.

;

;“I think it's very important to look at how celebrities or artists impact on our lives and the different facets of our life,” Beckett said.

;

;“Taylor Swift has such an outsized impact on elements of everyday life. For example, she's been credited with drawing attention back to public transport in a post-pandemic era. A lot of the cities she's going to – the public transport planners have been speaking out about adding extra services.”

;

;;Swiftonomics ;is already a well-trodden field, with economists analysing the effect of her Eras tour on the; singer's net worth;, as well as consumer spending, inflation and GDP.

;

;“I can't think of another artist, with perhaps the exception of Beyoncé, who has had quite the same economic impact,” Beckett said.

;

;Beckett, a xennial who grew up on a steady diet of goth and 90s grunge, said she came to Swift fandom relatively late, after being introduced to her music via her younger sister.

;

;“Some of those songs have seen me through some really dark times,” she said. “The Reputation album I really needed to hear it when that came out. I remember screaming along to it at the top of my lungs.”

;
;

;;Related: ;;'She is a snake – in the most positive way!' How Taylor Swift became the world's biggest pop star, again;

;
;

;Beckett said the singer's ability to build online community and parasocial relationships with fans was an area of growing academic interest. “The team behind [Swift] is a masterclass in PR and communications,” she said.

;

;The idea for the Swiftposium gained traction in July, when University of Melbourne cultural studies lecturer Hannah McCann flippantly tweeted her idea. She knew she was in trouble when it enchanted acafans (scholars who identify as fans) from Australia and across the pond. “Everyone rallied behind it,” said Beckett.

;

;“There is immense value in looking at these types of culture icons when they have this level of influence.”

;

;This is not the first time Swift has attracted academic interest. This year Belgium's Ghent University ;introduced an elective; titled Literature: Taylor's Version, which uses Swift's work as a springboard for exploring other writers.

;

;In 2022, New York University's Clive Davis Institute introduced ;a wide-ranging course on Swift;, while University of Texas English professor Elizabeth Scala founded a course titled The Taylor Swift Songbook.

;

;In November, Indiana University Bloomington ;will host a two-day conference; for “Swifties and Swifty-adjacent thinkers”.

; Fri, 22 Sep 2023 11:52:02 +0800 South Korea passes law to protect rights of teachers after mass protests over abuse from parentshttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/sep/22/south-korea-teachers-rights-laws-mass-protests-parents-abuse
;;2023-09-22T03:10:53Z;
;
;;Teachers protest in South Korea.
;

;South Korea has passed a set of legal revisions aimed at improving the rights of teachers in schools, following weeks of protests sparked by a series of teacher suicides said to be linked to malicious complaints from parents.

;

;The four bills, collectively known as the “teacher rights restoration bills” and passed at the national assembly on Thursday, represent a significant step towards enhancing the working conditions and protections for educators in the country.

;

;In particular, passage of one of the bills, which had unanimous support, means teachers will no longer be automatically suspended if they are accused of child abuse. The bill also prohibits school principals from downplaying or concealing activities that may have violated a teacher's rights.

;
;

;;Related: ;;Abused, traumatised and powerless: South Korea's teachers on why they are protesting;

;
;

;Teacher unions have welcomed the move.

;

;“The successful passage of these laws is thanks to the efforts of teachers who have taken to the streets every week […] We express our deep gratitude to them,” said the Korean Federation of Teachers Union.

;

;The Korean Teachers and Education Workers Union described the passage of the four bills as a “first step toward normalising public education and guaranteeing teaching authority”, but cautioned that achieving the full effectiveness of these laws may be challenging without sufficient manpower, budget support, and additional legislation.

;

;A controversial provision that would have allowed teachers to leave a record of students who violated teacher rights at school, potentially affecting their university admission prospects, was excluded from the final bills.

;

;The legal amendments follow weeks of protests and a ;large-scale walkout; by teachers ;expressing frustrations; over the abusive treatment they say they receive from both parents and students, including being accused of child abuse for disciplining students.

;

;The teachers' movement was sparked by the death of a 23-year-old primary school teacher in July. She was found dead at her school in Seoul in an apparent suicide after reportedly expressing anxiety over complaints from abusive parents. Since then, other teacher suicides suspected of being related to malicious complaints have come to light.

;

;In August, the government unveiled a set of guidelines to enhance teachers' rights, including measures to address abusive complaints. In Seoul, a chatbot service will be introduced in schools to deal with simple parental complaints on behalf of teachers.
